item.title: Emacser's guide: set up your osx like a BOSS
item.author: Zack Guo
item.description:
This is a “LTS” list of suggested tools(developer-leaning) runing on OS X based on my personal experiences, you can consider it as a starter tool kit for new machines and systems.

Basic Principles

  1. Less is more. Consider the OS X’s builtin functionalities at first!
  2. A good package manager saves your ass.
  3. CLI is better than GUI from time to time.

Starting Off

  1. Install Xcode Command Line Tools: xcode-select --install. Acutally install the Xcode GUI program is unnecessary if you are not a iOS or OSX developer since all other dev tools depend on Command Line Tools, not the Xcode GUI IDE.
  2. Install brew: brew.sh (the most popular OS X packages manager). Then brew doctor.

Emacs

Install pure Emacs from emacsformacosx.com. This is so far the best version running on osx comparing with others(e.g. Aquamacs). The goodies of using pure Emacs is let you take full control of everything and have the best compatibility.

Here is my dotEmacs!

Package for Packages

First of all, add melpa repo to Emacs:

(require 'package)
(add-to-list 'package-archives
  '("melpa" . "http://melpa.milkbox.net/packages/") t)
(package-initialize)
(add-to-list 'load-path "~/.emacs.d/site-lisp")    ; This may not be appeared if you have already added.

Basic Packages

  1. auto-complete
  2. base16-theme
  3. ecb
  4. flycheck
  5. magit
  6. rainbow-delimiters
  7. yasnippet
  8. ido
  9. smex
  10. volatile-highlight-mode
  11. markdown-mode
  12. yaml-mode
  13. color-theme

Javascript Packages

  1. js3-mode
  2. json-mode

Go Packages

  1. go-autocomplete
  2. go-mode
  3. go-lint
  4. go-eldoc
  5. go-direx (optinal)
  6. go-errcheck(optional)

Needed Go packages:

  1. gocode (go-autocomplete, go-eldoc)
  2. lint (go-lint)
  3. errcheck (go-errcheck)
  4. gotags (go-direx)

Clojure and ClojureScript

  1. clojure-mode
  2. cider
  3. pretty-symbols
  4. ac-nrepl
  5. paredit

Others

  1. ess (R programming)
  2. auctex (writing Tex)
  3. linum-relative (kinda cool)
  4. 2048-game
  5. git-gutter, git-gutter-fringe, fringe-helper

Dict and Spelling Checker

To work with flyspell-mode in Emacs I recommend using hunspell (which is the default checker in OS X) to replace default ispell:

;; now hunspell replaced ispell
(setq ispell-program-name "hunspell"
      ispell-local-dictionary "en_CA"
      ispell-skip-html t
      ispell-local-dictionary-alist
      '(("en_CA" "\[\[:alpha:\]\]" "[^[:alpha:]]" "[']" nil ("-d" "en_CA") nil utf-8)))
(setq ispell-dictionary "en_CA")

(add-hook 'markdown-mode-hook 'flyspell-mode) ;; for markdown-mode
(add-hook 'org-mode-hook 'flyspell-mode) ;; for org-mode

Download hunspell at sourceforge

Then download en dictionaries to /Library/Spelling :

US: en_US.aff en_US.dic

CA: en_CA.aff en_CA.dic

Other Dev Tools

Dash.app: Dash gives your Mac instant offline access to 150+ API documentation sets.

Google Chrome: Sometimes Safari is not enough.

Github for Mac: Easiest way to use Github on Mac.

Light Table: A promising ClojureScript powered IDE, especially for Clojure, ClojureScript and Javascript developing.

Slack: Team communicating, a better way than emails.

Visual Paradiam CE: Literally I do not like UML at all…

Multimedia and Others

MPlayerX: The recent versions are off Apple App Store, so do not install it from App Store.

MacTex: tex live on Mac.

Pages.app: Only recommend for quick dirty writing!

Mail.app: Every email app sucks, so let us just use the built-in app.

uTorrent: The popular torrent client.

Dictionary.app: I don’t see any needs to install a third-party dictionary. If it’s not enough, go online!

Conclusion

Do not turn you Mac into a mess! Install things only when you need it! @Gizak
